repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Close #12649 Allow fold mode where the buffer text (with highlights) is used for the fold text. To enable just set foldtext to an empty string: ```vim set foldtext= set fillchars=fold:\ ``` ```lua vim.o.foldtext = '' vim.o.fillchars = 'fold: ' ``` Supports: - extmarks highlights - legacy syntax highlighting - spell - conceal - inline virtual text - search highlighting - `fillchars:fold` is respected Does not support: - normal virtual text ### Preview: Shows search highlighting and inline virtual text

comment_data.body:
I think we usually use this to check whether an option is empty?
```suggestion
  const bool has_foldtext = has_fold && *wp->w_p_fdt != NUL;
```

Please consider moving up this closer to L148:
> 'foldtext' now supports virtual text format.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -289,6 +289,9 @@ The following new APIs and features were added.
 
 • Terminal buffers respond to OSC background and foreground requests. |default-autocmds|
 
+• |'foldtext'| can be set to an empty string to disable and render the line
+as normal with regular highlighting.

comment_data.body: I think you should also mention how a wrapped line is rendered.

comment_data.body: You need to add conditions below so that a folded line behaves like a non-wrapped line.

```suggestion
      const bool wrap1 = wrap                          // Wrapping enabled (and not a folded line).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2808,13 +2811,13 @@ int win_line(win_T *wp, linenr_T lnum, int startrow, int endrow, int col_rows, s
                 && wlv.p_extra != at_end_str)
             || (wlv.n_extra != 0 && (wlv.sc_extra != NUL || *wlv.p_extra != NUL))
             || has_more_inline_virt(&wlv, ptr - line))) {
-      const bool wrap = wp->w_p_wrap                  // Wrapping enabled.
-                        && wlv.filler_todo <= 0       // Not drawing diff filler lines.
-                        && lcs_eol_todo               // Haven't printed the lcs_eol character.
-                        && wlv.row != endrow - 1      // Not the last line being displayed.
-                        && (grid->cols == Columns     // Window spans the width of the screen,
-                            || ui_has(kUIMultigrid))  // or has dedicated grid.
-                        && !wp->w_p_rl;               // Not right-to-left.
+      const bool wrap1 = wrap                          // Wrapping enabled (or folded line).

comment_data.body:
I've introduced:

```c
  const bool wrap = wp->w_p_wrap
                    && !has_fold;       // Never wrap folded lines
```

and replaced all used of `wp->w_p_wrap` with it.
It may be better to move this to `winlinevars_T` so that the `wrap1` below can still be called `wrap`.

I'm not sure that really improves anything since you're still left with two variables named `wrap`, and it seems variables are arbitrarily added to `winlinevars_T`.

Is there a better name we can give to `wrap1`? I named it that to give some indication that it is different to `wrap`.
I just don't want make `wrap` refer to a different variable, as that may lead to mistakes. There will also be no mistakes if there are no variables named `wrap`. Maybe name this `is_wrapped` instead?
And... I think it's better to leave shorter or more general names for smaller scopes.
Done

```suggestion
      const bool wrap = is_wrapped                    // Wrapping enabled (not a folded line).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2795,14 +2804,14 @@ int win_line(win_T *wp, linenr_T lnum, int startrow, int endrow, int col_rows, s
 
     // At end of screen line and there is more to come: Display the line
     // so far.  If there is no more to display it is caught above.
-    if (wlv.col >= grid->cols && (!has_fold || virt_line_offset >= 0)
+    if (wlv.col >= grid->cols && (!has_foldtext || virt_line_offset >= 0)
         && (*ptr != NUL
             || wlv.filler_todo > 0
             || (wp->w_p_list && wp->w_p_lcs_chars.eol != NUL
                 && wlv.p_extra != at_end_str)
             || (wlv.n_extra != 0 && (wlv.sc_extra != NUL || *wlv.p_extra != NUL))
             || has_more_inline_virt(&wlv, ptr - line))) {
-      const bool wrap = wp->w_p_wrap                  // Wrapping enabled.
+      const bool wrap = is_wrapped                          // Wrapping enabled (not a folded line).

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        is displayed normally with highlighting and no line wrapping.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3181,6 +3181,9 @@ return {
 
         It is not allowed to change text or jump to another window while
         evaluating 'foldtext' |textlock|.
+
+        When set to an empty string, foldtext is disabled, and the line
+        is displayed normally with highlighting.

comment_data.body: I think this should still use `w_p_wrap`
This should still use `w_p_wrap` as showing "extends" character may make one think that they can scroll horizontally.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2629,10 +2638,10 @@ int win_line(win_T *wp, linenr_T lnum, int startrow, int endrow, int col_rows, s
     // 'list' is set.
     if (wp->w_p_lcs_chars.ext != NUL
         && wp->w_p_list
-        && !wp->w_p_wrap
+        && !is_wrapped

comment_data.body: Oh, actually it shouldn't, because it may cause problems with concealing.

```suggestion
  const int start_col = wp->w_p_wrap
```

```suggestion
        && (wp->w_p_wrap ? (wp->w_skipcol > 0 && wlv.row == 0) : wp->w_leftcol > 0)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2437,7 +2446,7 @@ int win_line(win_T *wp, linenr_T lnum, int startrow, int endrow, int col_rows, s
     // special character (via 'listchars' option "precedes:<char>".
     if (lcs_prec_todo != NUL
         && wp->w_p_list
-        && (wp->w_p_wrap ? (wp->w_skipcol > 0 && wlv.row == 0) : wp->w_leftcol > 0)
+        && (is_wrapped ? (wp->w_skipcol > 0 && wlv.row == 0) : wp->w_leftcol > 0)

comment_regular_data.body: Looks cool, I am hoping the `fancy_fold` can be set via options

This is just a low effort PR that just disables `'foldtext'` from being applied.

I'm thinking we could maybe allow `foldtext` to take a format similar to `virtual_text` to specify highlights and then make *unset*/*empty* `foldtext` behave as above.
Friendly ping -- is this something we should consider for 0.9 (even in a limited form)?
The implementation is fairly straightforward, need an API design to progress.

How about just allowing `foldtext` to be empty? (Without adding a new format, I mean.)

Or introduce a special value `NONE` that `foldtext()` can return.

> How about just allowing `foldtext` to be empty? (Without adding a new format, I mean.)

We can try this. A value of `''` would be totally useless anyway.
Other than maybe (or maybe not) adding a test, this is good to go. Really simple all things considered.
Good to go?
No tests?
I think this is subsumed in #23471
#23471 is actually orthogonal. I think we need to add a test since this is a drawline.c change.
Yes, but the PR includes these changes? (Agree that a test should be added, no matter where.)
That's only because I couldn't be bothered to deal with conflicts. When this is merged I'll rebase. I planned for this to go in first.

The current behavior of empty 'foldtext' is to show the number of folded lines, which seems to be the fastest way to show the number of folded lines on a fold (as it doesn't evaluate an expression). With this PR this is no longer possible. Maybe this can be enabled by setting 'foldtext' to something else that cannot be the start of an expression instead?

> The current behavior of empty 'foldtext' is to show the number of folded lines,

That is the behaviour when `foldexpr` errors or evaluates to `NULL`, it's just a fallback since `foldexpr` doesn't throw errors.

> which seems to be the fastest way to show the number of folded lines on a fold (as it doesn't evaluate an expression). With this PR this is no longer possible.

Why is this a desirable feature or requirement? Evaluating an expression isn't a problem and `foldtext()` shows the number of folded lines. IMO, this behaviour is just bad and most modern editors display the line as normal and highlight the background differently and/or add indicators in the column.

Additionally, we provide no real API for folds other than `foldclosed()` and `foldclosedend()` which is planned to be addressed with #19226.
Why close this?
@zeertzjq disagrees with this and I no longer want to work on this.
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25209 mostly covers the use-case here, no?
Not quite -- this is for showing the _actual_ highlights of the foldtext (first line of the folded section), see the screenshot in the PR description.
What's blocking this from going in now?

> @zeertzjq disagrees with this and I no longer want to work on this.

I see you reopened it, has this changed?

> Some variables in `win_update()` like `did_update` and `syntax_last_parsed` may need different updating.

Thanks for this.

I've added a fixup to update `syntax_last_parsed` and I don't think `did_update` needs changing since `DID_FOLD` is a stronger condition. I've also updated `spv_capcol_lnum`.

> I'm not able to reproduce the weird colors but I think I've fixed the tui crash.

The attr issue also seems resolved on my end.

If the promise is that folded lines take on all highlights, should spell highlighting also be applied? I.e. pass a non-zero `spellvars_T` to `win_line()` when `*wp->w_p_fdt == NUL`.

> If the promise is that folded lines take on all highlights, should spell highlighting also be applied? I.e. pass a non-zero spellvars_T to win_line() when *wp->w_p_fdt == NUL.

Ah, good catch. Fixed.

Ideally, we should render as much as possible. The only exceptions I'm aware of now is:
- virtual text is not displayed, though I'd like it to but this is difficult to implement given how virtual text is implemented.
- there is no wrap
Just to make sure: how about conceal?

> Just to make sure: how about conceal?

I haven't done any special handling for it, so there could be issues. Hopefully though it should just work since `win_line()` mostly reasons about grid positions.

EDIT: it looks like it works when I run `:<lnum1>,<lnum2>fold` in `vimdoc` files.
Just tested it, it works \o/ (at least for a naive test).
I guess that is one major reason to prefer this over `vim.treesitter.foldexpr()`, in addition to also rendering LSP semantic tokens (and any other extmarks).
Can we remove this, then? (I'd be OK with that; otherwise at least deprecate.)
Not my call since I didn't write it or merge it, but I would agree. It was also introduced this dev cycle so would it need deprecating?
(To be clear, we're talking about `vim.treesitter.foldtext`, not `foldexpr`.)
Yes

> > Not my call since I didn't write it or merge it, but I would agree. It was also introduced this dev cycle so would it need deprecating?
> 
> I feel a bit bad, too, because this was a (very nice) first contribution, but from the API maintenance point of view, it's a clear choice (pro removal).
> 
> @MariaSolOs (who guided the PR)

I feel a bit sad too, but if this represents a better alternative we can all agree that it's worth the pain.
I hope the (learning) effort wasn't wasted, at least, and we can hope for future PRs!

Just for the record: I think the ayes have it, as far as removing `vim.treesitter.foldtext()` is concerned.

And no deprecation necessary, but should be mentioned under `:h news-breaking-dev`.

> Just for the record: I think the ayes have it, as far as removing `vim.treesitter.foldtext()` is concerned.
> 
> And no deprecation necessary, but should be mentioned under `:h news-breaking-dev`.

Sure, but I think this should be done in a separate PR.

Not that it matters anymore, but I wrote the `vim.treesitter.foldtext` PR and I also vote to remove it, it was more of a proof of concept anyway and it doesn't make sense to treat treesitter special in this case. 

As for the learning effort, it wasn't wasted at all, I learned a bunch, and it also removed the anxiousness one might have before submitting their first PR to a big project. I'll certainly contribute again if I find something that I can help with.

You could make a PR to remove it again, if you want ;)

In any case, looking forward to the next high-quality contribution!

title: feat(folds): transparent fold text
